awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Controlled-Environment Atomic Force Microscope for Nanoelectronic Characterization
awd_abstract_narration:
Acquisition of an advanced atomic force microscope system within a controlled environment glove box enables imaging of solid surfaces with a resolution near the scale of individual atoms while simultaneously measuring the properties of the surfaces at each location. This microscope provides the ability to directly relate the structure and properties of a surface to how it was made and how it performs, which lies at the heart of materials science and engineering research. These materials relationships give researchers the information needed to create advanced materials for a range of applications. Critically, the controlled environment capabilities allow research to be performed on materials that cannot be exposed to air or moisture. Housed within the Surface Science Laboratory at Boise State University, this instrument expands research capacity in Idaho and meets the needs of a broad research community, including five universities, several local industries, and two national laboratories. The principal investigators have a proven, rigorous, and industry-recognized model for training undergraduate and graduate students in atomic force microscopy. The controlled-environment microscope exposes these students to the current state-of-the-art instrument and better prepares them for success in graduate school and careers in academia and industry. With active community outreach, the new microscope showcases advanced materials research capabilities and inspires elementary and high school students to pursue careers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics.

The controlled-environment atomic force microscope provides an important tool for materials research at Boise State University by enabling advanced nanoelectronic  characterization of air-and moisture-sensitive materials. The new capabilities provided by this system include inert-environment Kelvin probe microscopy for nanoscale surface potential measurements and scanning electrochemical microscopy for in-situ monitoring of electrochemical reactions. The microscope enables interdisciplinary and collaborative materials research in (1) the controlled integration of DNA nanostructures with semiconductor surfaces for sub-lithographic patterning of memory devices; (2) the nanoscale origins of corrosion mechanisms in metal alloys to enable fabrication of high-performance aerospace structural components and biomedical implants; (3) interphase evolution and electrochemical activity of air-sensitive metal-ion battery electrodes for stable, safe, and high-capability energy storage; (4) the effects of synthesis and processing conditions on the electronic and thermal properties of air-sensitive 2-dimensional materials for flexible and energy-efficient electronics; and (5) real-time observation of ion channel formation in air-sensitive phase change materials for novel memory devices for extreme environments.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to provide advanced research instrumentation and training opportunities to students, faculty, and staff through the acquisition of a state-of-the-art controlled-environment atomic force microscope (AFM) with advanced capabilities. An AFM is an instrument for studying the surface features and surface properties of materials at very small scales, spanning the nano to microscale. AFM provides important capabilities for the study and development of new materials for use in a variety of applications ranging from structural metals to batteries to semiconductor devices.

The AFM acquired through this project filled a gap in characterization capabilities, and the intellectual merit of this project stemmed from the advanced research in materials science and engineering that it enabled. The specific objective of this project was to acquire and operate an AFM within a controlled atmosphere glovebox using standard AFM modes as well as advanced modes, including Kelvin probe force microscopy (KPFM) and scanning electrochemical microscopy (SECM). These unique capabilities advance knowledge by enabling research of materials that are air or moisture sensitive, such as new materials for battery electrodes. The advanced modes of KPFM and SECM provide methods to study the electrical properties of material surfaces. KPFM allows the study of the differences in voltage at the surface of an alloy to gain insight into how these surface voltages contribute to the onset of corrosion. SECM allows the study of battery materials while they are being charged and discharged, which allows the study and design of safer, more stable materials with greater storage capacity. Additionally, beyond enabling the characterization of moisture sensitive materials, the controlled environment of the AFM allows greater resolution of surface features and properties which advances knowledge of nanoscale materials. To share the knowledge gained with the instrument, the studies completed with the controlled-environment AFM have been published in leading peer-reviewed scientific journals.

The instrument acquired through this project is a state-of-the-art system and the only one like it in the Pacific Northwest. In addition to advancing knowledge through its unique capabilities, the system has provided new opportunities to undergraduate and graduate students, as well as postdoctoral scientists. Six undergraduate students, including four female students, and three graduate students have been trained to operate the instrument. The figure below shows the glovebox AFM being operated by an undergraduate student. These students have been co-authors on the peer-reviewed publications and conference presentations that report data acquired from the instrument. Thus, this instrument has expanded opportunities for students to work with state-of-the-art instrumentation, including students from underrepresented groups. The instrument has expanded research capacity at Boise State University and in Idaho, and the research it enabled will have an impact on the broader community through the new knowledge gained.


Last Modified: 12/28/2021
Modified by: Elton Graugnard

Image
  • Undergraduate student and Surface Science Lab employee uses the controlled-environment atomic force microscope.
    John Kelly

    Elton Graugnard
